My question concerns the details of computation of the expectation value: $$ $$ From the sigmoid activation function we have this probability that a hidden unit will be active: $$P(h_j=1) = \sigma(b_j + \Sigma(v_iw_{ij})) $$ My understanding is that we actually want to *sample* $$P(h_i=1)$$ from the distribution in order to stochastically explore the weight space(?) So in other words, we sample $$h_i$$ using a pseudo-random method with probability P and then take: (Number of times vi and hj were both on in the mini-batch) / N Where N=size of mini-batch and n=index within mini-batch. So my first question is just to verify that the above is correct. Secondly can $$h_i$$ be sampled multiple times for one input, say 10 times per training input and then divided by 10N? Alternatively, rather than sampling, what if this probability were instead averaged for each training example over the mini-batch, such as: $$\frac{\Sigma_n(P(h_j=1)*v_i)}{N}$$ I realize that is not really correct because expected value is not multiplicitave unless the 2 random variables are conditionally independent (covariance is zero). But would this provide a (perhaps faster) approximation, or is collecting statistics from sampling necessary? I'm guessing the answers to some of these questions might best be answered by trying it out, but just wondering if any opinions on the subject.

This is what an HMM does.

What does it even mean for HMM to 'remember' smth? It has just one state at a certain moment of time.
Upvotes:
1
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Here's a high level description: suppose I flip a coin over and over, and each time I ask you to tell me the result 5 time steps ago, so if the sequence of past flips is ... H H T H T then you need to be able to tell me H. You can then discard this knowledge and store the knowledge of the next flip. In other words, you need to store 5 bits of information in order to be able to memorize 5 steps into the past. How can we encode 5 bits of information? Well one way is to use binary numbers, so 00000 through 11111. An alternative way is to have a single vector of length $$2^5$$ where each index corresponds to a particular binary number. This is what an HMM does.

Instructor's Post
Hi everyone, I'll double check with professor Hinton to make sure I'm not getting the message wrong, but my interpretation is this: Think about the general description 'two roughly parallel lines with a red dot in the middle'. This describes a very large number of possibilities, but they would all have this high level description in common. Yes, that would include lots of translations, scalings, rotations, and possibly many other transformations (are they lines drawn on a piece of paper or two metal rods or something else?). In other words, it's a level of abstraction that groups together many seemingly different looking things and is therefore invariant to the low-level details of those things. So this is just a description of an invariant feature, but what about actually using it? Well you can imagine that if we knew how to identify this feature in an image then we would have some piece of software that outputs a '1' if this feature is present and '0' otherwise. We might even want it to output the coordinates of where this feature occurred instead of just whether it occurred. Any higher level systems (like where to peck for food) would then use this sub-system. This is a very abstract feature though, and so building this software is very tricky. We don't know in advance all of the kinds of variations that we would need to deal with, and explicitly dealing with the ones we do know about is not easy. One intuitive idea that seems to help is to first extract low-level features and then combine them to make high level features. So if we had features for lines and features for red dots, then it would be easier to combine them than just looking for the whole thing from scratch (and we can maybe use them for other abstract features too). When we build a neural network, the hope is that the network will automatically learn to extract whatever useful low/high-level representations are needed to solve the task we give it. However, if we have some advanced knowledge of how to deal with common factors of variation then we might as well use it. A convolutional network (with pooling) is designed to create abstract high level representations that are invariant to translation. As it turns out, this is very helpful in object recognition since objects can appear all over the image. Given this additional bit of help, the network then 'picks up the slack' for the rest of the features. There has also been work in explicitly dealing with other kinds of variations like rotation, lighting, etc. Hope this helps!
